oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Bobby Bare Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Bobby Bare (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bobby Bare; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Bobby Bare talks about being born in Ironton, Ohio and how the city got its name -- (01:03) Bare talks about living with family in Kentucky when his mother got sick -- (02:24) Bare talks about his sister Lois being adopted by his neighbors -- (03:14) Bare talks about working for a quarter an hour at a chicken farm and working for farmers -- (05:11) Biff Collie and Bare talk about Bare's ability to create guitars in his youth -- (06:29) Bare remembers playing "Back in the Saddle Again" by Gene Autry as his first song and talks about his family's musical skills -- (07:58) Bare recalls the first time singing in front of anybody was singing a capella before Christmas and singing "Shotgun Boogie" at the talent show -- (09:01) "Sleeping at the Foot of the Bed" by Little Jimmy Dickens is discussed along with Bare seeing Dickens play -- (10:08) Bare talks about leaving home to live with his grandma in Springfield, Ohio and starting a band while playing in a club -- (11:55) Bare talks about being over paid by his store owner and not being used to making money -- (13:04) Bare talks about working for Slim McCoy and then a radio station with his band -- (13:54) Bare talks about a Kenny King [Unconfirmed] and playing bass / singing for his band -- (14:46) Bare talks about working fairs and lying about his age to work on trucks at International Harvester -- (15:39) Bare talks about doing multiple radio spots, one with WKOV and working in a club at the same time -- (16:55) Bare talks about getting a large amount of mail and his sudden popularity -- (18:12) Bare discusses his sudden interest in recording , working at the Stones Grill, and describing a "Nuddie Suit" -- (19:42) Bare received an offer for connections in California and talking to the band before leaving for California -- (21:22) Bare notices how the back window of the convertible was busted and when they stopped realized they were all broke -- (22:30) Bare recalls talking to a waitress and placing money in a jukebox instead of getting cigarettes -- (23:34) Bare discussed his next move of setting up in a bar and working purely for tips to get them through Texas -- (24:14) Bare talks about working for people in New Mexico and Tuscan, Arizona -- (25:00) Bare talks about going to The Open Door, a bar, and finding out there was a singer there about to go on the road with Ray Price -- (25:50) Bare talks about going to the Hula Hut and being hired on the spot despite not being twenty-one yet -- (27:24) Bare talks about being invited by a Jennie Smith [Unconfirmed] to perform and almost not being allowed to because of his age -- (29:11) Bare talks about working for three years before being sent up to Alaska -- (31:54) Bare returned to California and got a job driving a truck while attempting to write songs -- (32:56) Bare talks about working in multiple venues at the same time while getting his first record deal -- (35:05) Bare talks about living in a home with other recording artists -- (36:30) Bare talks about his record Down on the Corner of Love and how it got him work in a couple clubs -- (37:44) Bare talks about working New Years Eve and the growing crowds -- (38:50) Bare discusses how he was able to get the lease for The Ballroom and how he operated his club until his draft call from Springfield, Ohio (40:19) Bare talks about cutting some demos in Cincinnati before leaving for Fort Knox and how Fraternity Records wanted to release his cut even though he was under contract -- (42:25) Bare talked about getting dropped off at Fort Knox and someone smuggling in a radio to basic and hearing himself on the radio -- (43:31) Bare talks about his fellow recording artist Bill Parsons coming to him about the popularity of their combined record and how they both had to lie about Bare's contributions -- (44:55) Bare talked about how his song had become a "smash hit" and how Parsons was a part of the tour in which Buddy Holly died -- (46:19) Bare's secret was exposed and Bare became a member of Fraternity Records when he was out of the service -- (47:45) Bare talks about coming to Nashville and meeting Chet Atkins to discuss cutting some records including "Shame on Me" -- (49:18) Bare talks about recording "Detroit City" and going fishing with Jimmy Bryant before his career took off -- (50:13) Bare talked about going over to Warner Brothers to audition for a part and being placed in "A Distant Trumpet" -- (52:00) Bare talks about denying the Warner Brothers' television offer -- (52:47) Bare talks about recording "500 Miles From Home" -- (53:09) Bare talks about joining the Opry and getting to Nashville -- (53:57) Bare recalls the stress of being a film star, preferring being a part of being a country star, and the birth of his children -- (55:51) Bare talks about his friend Kris Krisofferson who came to Nashville to become a song writer (57:40) Bare talks about writing "When I Loved Her" and "Loving Her is Easier" with Krisofferson -- (58:38) Bare talks about working with Shel Silverstein on "Lullabys, Legends And Lies" -- (59:48) Bare discussed working with Billy Joe Shaver for a number of years and "Ride Me Down Easy" -- (1:01:50) Bare discusses working with Tom T. Hall and sharing offices together -- (1:02:35) Bare discusses encouraging Hall and recording with Guy Clark -- (1:03:37) Bare talks about recording Waylon Jennings' tracks and meeting him in Arizona and watching him perform -- (106:35) Bare talked about housing Jennings and using each other for recording even to the day of the recording -- (107:32) Bare talks about going on the first country music tour to go to Europe and the lose of Jim Reeves -- (1:08:23) Bare loves hanging out with song writers, calling them the "base" of country music -- (1:10:20) Bare talks about his uncle Teddy Bare and setting up a teddy bear shop and purchasing a ten foot tall teddy bear-- (1:12:12) Bare talks about how his bear shop has taken off every Fan Fair (1:13:03) Bare provides the directions to his business and signs off
